content.description: Climb the arete right of Aqualung on TR.

A corner similar to Aqualung in appearance offers moderate climbing with great gear along the way. A single crack splits into two halfway up resembling a "crutch." this is an excellent warm up or cool down other than its commonly climbed predecessor.
content.protection: An Orange Metolius, a Red C3, and #3 Camalot, in that order, are three unobvious placements to safely get you up the start. After that, a standard rack from a #.3 to #3 will lead you safely to the top. Nuts and slings helpful.
content.location: Appx. 100 ft left of Aqualung following a black streak up an obvious line to the rim.

content.description:
Downstream from Aqualung is corner up to a roof.   Climb the corner to the roof, turn the roof (crux) and if you get the gear right, continue to the top.  If instead, you runner your gear short, as I did, then your rope drag will be horrendous and I ended up belaying on the slopes above the roof.  Thus a 2 pitch route at the forks. 

  Actually the climb to the roof and getting over the roof is good.  Turning the roof seemed tricky. 

  On the "2nd" pitch, a fist size rock was knocked off and beaned me in the head, requiring a few stiches (pre helmet days, unless you count the pumpkin sized Joe Browns.  There's more to this story but that's going to cost someone some beers since it's somewhat embarassing and involved.   

  After a few ascents, the rest of whatever is loose should clean up.   My recollection is that the second bit is 5.8 which partially accounts for my lack of attention that day.  

  You can also climb out to the right on lower angle ramps.   There might be a decent easy route in the corners to the right of the roof and up to the ramp?
content.location: Can't recall just how far down stream.  Not all that far and it's the most obvious roof in the area.

climbs.name: Jungle Jive
climbs.fa: Jim Haisley, Paul Davidson, Tim Coats

content.description: No claims have been made that this is Jungle Jive. Probably is, maybe its not but it does sit between Dump Truck and Lost In Space? The climbing does closely match Toula's description of "5.11 stem box (mossy)â€œ. The ambiguity and the fact that this route hides completely behind the three largest Fir trees has kept Jungle Jive a hidden classic. Possibly one the better stem routes at the Forks, Jungle Jive climbs a rememberable twin seam elevator shaft. Do some laps on D.D. and get your butt muscles prepped to Jive.
content.protection: Mostly Thin:   Comfortable amount of #00 C3 - Fingers   1x others   #4 optional at the start   Nuts and Butts   Runners
content.location: Meander somewhat to the middle of The Jungle Wall. Hidden behind the three largest Fir trees. Look for the obvious twin seams in a steep elevator shaft. Starts in the bobbles.

climbs.name: Bear Necessities
climbs.fa: Mike Robinson, Jeff Snyder, Jeff Peabody

content.description: Speculated to be the best new route at the forks for 2016 ( also the only one) The bear necessities until now lay hidden behind a curtain of lichen camo. It was likely top roped some time in the dark ages but judging by the condition of the route it doubtfully has seen a lead. From the belay ledge head of the right crack and quickly transfer to the middle finger ish crack . After some fun moves in the .5 size crack with good stems, reach over and transfer into the far left thin hands crack. Ride the splitter up as it goes form 1's to 3's and then get ready for the roof. Glory hand jams and good feet will bring you out of the right side of the roof that finishes the route off.
content.protection: doubles .4 to 3, bring a few extra finger pieces to make the belay on the ledge.
content.location: just to the right of Jangala, on the far left side of the jungle wall, rap down and make a gear anchor on the belay ledge. the rap line can be set of the the prominent horn on the left side of the jungle wall and backed up with a huge pine tree

content.description: Aqualung is a demanding finger to hand crack line over on the right (west) end of the Jungle Wall, across from East Of Eden. Start at a nice finger crack in a stem-box corner of golden rock. Crank your way up the finger crack (crux) to reach the hand crack above, which is followed to the rim.
content.protection: Nuts, small (0 TCU) to large (#3 Camalot) cams. It is possible to place a #4 Camalot sized piece in this route, if you want to take it along.

content.description:
A unique line for the Forks, save for one pinky lock there is no jamming on this route. The line starts in a shallow dihedral on bobble rock which leads to a short slab. From here reach high and place a #2 BD nut and a blue ball nut and launch into the refrigerator wrestling boulder problem, followed by big moves on positive holds to the top.   

  NOTE : A lot of the gear is quite small and specific on the route, I highly recommend sussing it before leading the route.
content.protection:
Thin, I used the following. 

  3x #000 C3   2x #00 C3   Blue Ball Nut   #2 BD Nut   #3 BD Nut   #5 Offset   #6 Offset   #8 BD Nut   .3 C4   #3 C4 (For the very top)
content.location: Across from the prow there are two dead trees on the edge of the Jungle wall, Americans In The Jungle is located directly below the left one. It is also the next line left of Jungle Jive

content.description: The Jungle Wall is found directly across the canyon from the Gold Wall and is the north-facing wall south of the Gold Pond. The rock tends to be not as good as other areas here, and tends to gather dirt from rim erosion, so it is less visited than those areas. At least one route should be done here, Aqualung (5.10), across from East Of Eden (Gold Wall), a really nice finger to hand crack on relatively clean rock.
